<!-- Please use this template while reporting a bug and provide as much info as possible. Not doing so may result in your bug not being addressed in a timely manner. Thanks!-->


**What happened**:
After upgrading to kube-proxy `1.12.5`, the ClusterIP will be disconnected when restarting kube-proxy. When a service uses ClusterIP to connect to other services, it will be affected. As shown in the figure, during the kube-proxy restart, the response time is obviously slower.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4145852/51508755-a317fd80-1e31-11e9-9995-febec4cfba0b.png)

When back to kube-proxy `1.11.4`, no this problem. this is the log, attention the time, kube-proxy restart at `10:27:09`, see the picture above, response time at the time is normal.
```
Log file created at: 2019/01/22 10:27:09
Running on machine: k8s-node-pushd
Binary: Built with gc go1.10.3 for linux/amd64
Log line format: [IWEF]mmdd hh:mm:ss.uuuuuu threadid file:line] msg
I0122 10:27:09.971242   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --alsologtostderr="true"
I0122 10:27:09.971512   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --bind-address="0.0.0.0"
I0122 10:27:09.971521   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --cleanup="false"
I0122 10:27:09.971528   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --cleanup-iptables="false"
I0122 10:27:09.971532   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --cleanup-ipvs="true"
I0122 10:27:09.971536   14444 flags.go:27] FLAG: --cluster-cidr=""
```

### Another scene
when use kube-proxy `1.12.5` , ClusterIP of `coredns` will also be disconnected, name resolve will failed
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4145852/51509117-00f91500-1e33-11e9-8721-68fd275d237d.png)


**What you expected to happen**:
ClusterIP won't lost connection when kube-proxy restart

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
Use kube-proxy `1.12.5`

**Anything else we need to know?**:
Add flag  `--cleanup-ipvs=false` ,  same result
```
Log file created at: 2019/01/22 11:15:24
Running on machine: k8s-node-pushd
Binary: Built with gc go1.10.7 for linux/amd64
Log line format: [IWEF]mmdd hh:mm:ss.uuuuuu threadid file:line] msg
I0122 11:15:24.262837   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --alsologtostderr="true"
I0122 11:15:24.263066   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --bind-address="0.0.0.0"
I0122 11:15:24.263075   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --cleanup="false"
I0122 11:15:24.263081   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --cleanup-iptables="false"
I0122 11:15:24.263085   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --cleanup-ipvs="false"
I0122 11:15:24.263089   27865 flags.go:33] FLAG: --cluster-cidr=""
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4145852/51510351-b62dcc00-1e37-11e9-803d-8cd915320c9b.png)

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):  1.12.5
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: 
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release):  CentOS 7
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):  3.10
- Install tools:  manual
- Others:
